title: Potential difference change when switch closes

content.question: Four resistors and an open switch <math alttext="S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> are connected to a battery of unknown <math alttext="e m f script E" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mi>e</mi><mi>m</mi><mi>f</mi></mstyle><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mi>ε</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> in the circuit shown above. The switch is initially open. Which of the following is true about the potential across the <math alttext="18 ohm" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>18</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> resistor after the switch is closed?

choices.label: It increases because the total resistance of the circuit decreases.

It decreases because initially the <math alttext="6 ohm" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="18 ohm" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>18</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> resistors split the battery <math alttext="e m f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>m</mi><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and afterward the <math alttext="9 ohm" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>9</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="18 ohm" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>18</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> resistors split the battery <math alttext="e m f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>m</mi><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

It decreases because initially the <math alttext="6 ohms" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="18 ohms" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>18</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> resistors split the battery <math alttext="e m f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>m</mi><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> proportionally, and afterward the <math alttext="6 ohms" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="18 ohms" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>18</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> resistors split the battery <math alttext="e m f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>m</mi><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> evenly.

It remains the same because the ratio of the <math alttext="6 ohm" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="18 ohm" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>18</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> resistances is the same as the ratio <math alttext="equivalent resistance of 3 ohm and 6 ohm resistors, to, equivalent resistance of 9 ohm and 18 ohm resistors" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi><mi>u</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>v</mi><mi>a</mi><mi>l</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>n</mi><mi>t</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>r</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>s</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>s</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>tan</mi><mi>c</mi><mi>e</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>o</mi><mi>f</mi></mstyle><mtext> </mtext><mn>3</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mtext> </mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>n</mi><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mn>6</mn><mtext> </mtext></mstyle><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi><mtext> </mtext><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mi>r</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>s</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>s</mi><mi>t</mi><mi>o</mi><mi>r</mi><mi>s</mi></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi><mi>u</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>v</mi><mi>a</mi><mi>l</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>n</mi><mi>t</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>r</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>s</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>s</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>tan</mi><mi>c</mi><mi>e</mi><mtext> </mtext><mi>o</mi><mi>f</mi><mtext> </mtext></mstyle><mn>9</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mtext> </mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>n</mi><mi>d</mi><mtext> </mtext></mstyle><mn>18</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mtext> </mtext><mi>r</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>s</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>s</mi><mi>t</mi><mi>o</mi><mi>r</mi><mi>s</mi></mstyle></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>.

content.answer: It remains the same because the ratio of the <math alttext="6 ohm" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="18 ohm" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>18</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> resistances is the same as the ratio <math alttext="equivalent resistance of 3 ohm and 6 ohm resistors, to, equivalent resistance of 9 ohm and 18 ohm resistors" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi><mi>u</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>v</mi><mi>a</mi><mi>l</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>n</mi><mi>t</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>r</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>s</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>s</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>tan</mi><mi>c</mi><mi>e</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>o</mi><mi>f</mi></mstyle><mtext> </mtext><mn>3</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mtext> </mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>n</mi><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mn>6</mn><mtext> </mtext></mstyle><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi><mtext> </mtext><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mi>r</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>s</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>s</mi><mi>t</mi><mi>o</mi><mi>r</mi><mi>s</mi></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi><mi>u</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>v</mi><mi>a</mi><mi>l</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>n</mi><mi>t</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>r</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>s</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>s</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>tan</mi><mi>c</mi><mi>e</mi><mtext> </mtext><mi>o</mi><mi>f</mi><mtext> </mtext></mstyle><mn>9</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mtext> </mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>n</mi><mi>d</mi><mtext> </mtext></mstyle><mn>18</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mtext> </mtext><mi>r</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>s</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>s</mi><mi>t</mi><mi>o</mi><mi>r</mi><mi>s</mi></mstyle></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>.

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
